data.text: @KnifeMackthe I share your skepticism. I tend to take most measures of inequality with a grain of salt, but after reviewing the methodology I still think it is worth a gander.

@Partisan_O I have not looked at this website but I would recommend caution on most Left generated income inequality studies: Starting with Piketty’s inequality there has been a tendency to ignore public transfers like Social Security and govt pensions. Include those and most ineq drops
@Partisan_O The first part of my post is, I'm suspecting due to many middle 40's home equity growing a lot in the past 10 years.

@Partisan_O There is a setting for household wealth and it's interesting  that the middle 40%'s household wealth grew faster than the top 10% over the past 10 yrs. The very richest seem to pull ahead the most in the true boom years, late 90s / mid 00s, and not do as poorly in the bust.
I’m more interested in household wealth than individual income, but thought I’d add that last pic for good measure.
